intro: Cyrilla nipensis, commonly known as the Florida cyrilla, is a deciduous shrub native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Lythraceae, which includes plants such as willows and poinsettias. The plant is characterized by its simple, opposite leaves and clusters of small, red flowers that bloom in the spring. Cyrilla nipensis typically grows in wetlands, swamps, and along the edges of ponds, preferring moist, acidic soils. It plays an important role in supporting local wildlife, particularly birds and insects.
